docs.lead_paragraph: The health insurance industry may have envisioned a low-key wonk session when it planned its ''state issues'' annual conference this year. But the conference, scheduled for Thursday and Friday in Washington, comes at a crucial phase of the battle over health care legislation. The event could prove more lively than expected, with protesters planning to show up in droves.
docs.abstract: Health insurance industry's annual 'state issues' conference could prove more lively than expected because it comes at crucial phase of battle over health care legislation and protesters are planning to show up in droves (M)
docs.snippet: The health insurance industry may have envisioned a low-key wonk session when it planned its ''state issues'' annual conference this year.      But the conference, scheduled for Thursday and Friday in Washington, comes at a crucial phase of the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The health insurance industry may have envisioned a low-key wonk session when it originally planned its "state issues" annual conference this year.

headline.main: Protests Planned at Insurance Industry Conference

docs.abstract: Protesters plan to show up in droves at a conference the insurance industry plans to hold Thursday and Friday in Washington.
docs.snippet: Protesters plan to show up in droves at a conference the insurance industry plans to hold Thursday and Friday in Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee has quietly recommended that millions elderly Americans who buy Medigap plans be charged new co-pays for doctor's visits starting in 2015.

headline.main: For Seniors, Hidden Costs in a Senate Bill

docs.abstract: The Senate Finance Committee's health care bill would require some seniors with Medigap policies to begin chipping in co-payments.
docs.snippet: The Senate Finance Committee's health care bill would require some seniors with Medigap policies to begin chipping in co-payments.

docs.lead_paragraph: In August, news that the United States Postal Service was planning to close 14 of New York City's roughly 250 post offices elicited an outcry from residents and politicians alike, who clamored to protect their local branches.

headline.main: Council May Urge Congress to Save Post Offices

docs.abstract: The City Council's Committee on Governmental Operations held an hour-long hearing on a resolution urging Congress to pass two bills that could help prevent the shuttering of hundreds of post offices nationwide.
docs.snippet: The City Council's Committee on Governmental Operations held an hour-long hearing on a resolution urging Congress to pass two bills that could help prevent the shuttering of hundreds of post offices nationwide.

docs.lead_paragraph: Critics claim the health insurance industry was acting in bad faith when it released a controversial report last week from PricewaterhouseCoopers that suggested insurance premiums would rise sharply in the wake of proposed legislation to overhaul the market. As my colleague David M. Herszenzhorn has noted, the report was seen by many Democrats as an act of open aggression by the insurers.

headline.main: Insurers' Trade Group Defends Controversial Report

docs.abstract: The president of the health insurers' trade association defends a controversial report.
docs.snippet: The president of the health insurers' trade association defends a controversial report.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ezra Klein has an excellent update on the efforts of Ron Wyden, a Democratic senator from Oregon, to make sure health reform gives people greater ability to choose their own insurance plans. As we've written before, the current health bill -- both the Senate and House versions -- would do nothing for people who don't like the insurance choices their employer now offers. They would be stuck with them.

headline.main: They Say You'll Have a Choice. You Won't.

docs.abstract: The current versions of health-care reform would not give people more freedom to choose their own health insurance.
docs.snippet: The current versions of health-care reform would not give people more freedom to choose their own health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama is looking to scoop up big money for Democrats at a $30,400-a-couple fund-raiser in Manhattan on Tuesday night. But he will not forget the little people.

headline.main: Obama to Rally Democratic Supporters in Manhattan

docs.abstract: The president reaches out to supporters who were instrumental during his campaign.
docs.snippet: The president reaches out to supporters who were instrumental during his campaign.

docs.lead_paragraph: Regular Agenda readers have perhaps caught on that this column is, shall we say, skeptical about the employer mandate crafted by Max Baucus, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. We're not alone. Last week, commenting on one of The Agenda's analyses, a reader, Peter Lee, alerted us to another critique. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal-leaning group focusing on income inequality, takes issue with the Baucus bill's mandate on other grounds.

headline.main: More Reasons to Doubt the Baucus Mandate

docs.abstract: Some critics say that the employer mandate created by the Senate Finance Committee will keep companies from hiring low-income people.
docs.snippet: Some critics say that the employer mandate created by the Senate Finance Committee will keep companies from hiring low-income people.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama will resume his role as top Democratic fund-raiser in New York on Tuesday, but one group may be conspicuous in its absence.

headline.main: The Early Word: New York Bound

docs.abstract: The president heads to New York for a fund-raiser, but some of Wall Street's heavy hitters won't be showing up.
docs.snippet: The president heads to New York for a fund-raiser, but some of Wall Street's heavy hitters won't be showing up.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Wall Street giants that received a financial lifeline from Washington may have no compunction about paying big bonuses to their dealmakers and traders. But their willingness to deliver "thank you" gifts to President Obama and the Democrats is another question altogether, The New York Times's David D. Kirkpatrick writes.

headline.main: Financial Giants Donating Little to Obama Party

docs.abstract: The Wall Street giants that received a financial lifeline from Washington may have no compunction about paying big bonuses to their dealmakers and traders, but their willingness to deliver "thank you" gifts to President Obama is another question altogether.
